Short Review
Thermal conductive composites reinforced via advanced boron nitride nanomaterials
Chenyang Xua, Meng Miaoa, Xiangfen Jiangb, Xuebin Wanga,⁎
aNational Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures, Collaborative Innovation Center of Advanced Microstructures, College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China b International Center for Materials Nanoarchitectonics (MANA), National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), Tsukuba 3050044, Japan
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Boron nitride Thermal conductivity Polymeric composite Dimension
A B S T R A C T
The demand for insulating polymeric composites with high thermal conductivity has increased remarkably for electronic packaging. Since polymers usually suffer from low thermal conductivity, boron nitrides (BN) are emerging as advanced fillers in polymeric composites. BN nanomaterials strikingly reinforce thermal conductivity of polymers and simultaneously improve insulation, thermal expansion, and dielectricity. We herein introduce diverse BN nanomaterials and summarize the progress about thermal conductive composites with various BN fillers from 0D BN particles via 1D nanotubes to 2D nanosheets. 3D fillers, multi-scale and multidimensional mixed BN fillers developed recently are also presented. The functionalization and the controlled orientation of fillers are reviewed, and current challenges towards higher thermal conductivity of BN/polymer composites are additionally discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction to boron nitride nanomaterials
sections.text:
Boron nitride (BN) low-dimensional materials can be traced back to 1990s [1], following carbon fullerene [2], which have been ascending [3,4]. The development of BN nanomaterials is bound with their graphitic counterparts as similar bond energy but different frontier electron structures between graphite and hexagonal BN [5–7]. BN implements wide applications such as water purification [8], medicine [9], electronics [10], polymeric composites [11], etc. The theoretical thermal conductivity of BN is up to 2000W/mK [12], and BN is also an excellent insulator. It is hence favored for insulating thermal conductive materials. This review discusses BN nanomaterials as advanced fillers for thermal conductive polymeric composites.
There exist varieties of dimensions of BN nanomaterials: zero dimension (0D), one dimension (1D), two dimension (2D), and three dimension (3D). They are generally produced via two ways: top-down methods such as mechanical exfoliation, chemical exfoliation and unzipping, and bottom-up ones like chemical vapor deposition (CVD). The BN nanomaterials are shortly illustrated as follows:
i) 0D BN fullerenes and nanoparticles. BN fullerene had been proposed, yet it was not until 1998 that a single-layered octahedral BN fullerene was fabricated by Golberg et al. [1]. After that, BN nanoparticles were produced in large scale [13].
ii) 1D BN nanotube (BNNT). Following carbon nanotubes [14], BNNT was achieved using arc-discharge by Chopra et al. in 1995 [15]. Mass production of BNNT was then developed by ball-milling [16], floating catalysts [17], boron-oxide CVD [18], etc.
iii) 2D BN nanosheet (BNNS). Sparked by the discovery of graphene [19], Novoselov et al. peeled single-layered BNNS by mechanical exfoliation in 2005 [20]. BNNS were subsequently synthesized in several methods. In 2010, Shi et al. grew few-layered BNNS on nickel using CVD [21]. In 2011, Wang et al. developed a chemical blowing route to massively produce BNNS [22], and Li et al. reported an improved exfoliation approach for BNNS [23]. Wang et al. also developed a biomass-based carbothermic reduction method to greatly increase the output of high-quality BNNS [24]. iv) 3D porous BN. Porous BN, intriguing for high specific surface area, usually processes nano-scaled pore walls. It can also be viewed as a 3D nanomaterial. It was produced via template methods or nontemplate ones. Han et al. produced a porous BN using the hard template of activated carbon [25], while Malenfant et al. accomplished it via a soft-template of polynorbornene-decaborane [26]. In template-free syntheses, 3D BN foams were produced via a chemical blowing route and an improved one by Wang et al. [22] and Xue et al. [27] respectively.

sections.heading: 2.1. General concepts
sections.text:
The past decade has witnessed an expeditious progress in the study of thermal conductive composites. In insulating solid, thermal conduction means the ability to transfer vibrational energy between adjacent particles [28]. From a microscopic viewpoint, it ascribes to phonon transport, which vital concept is phonon scattering. The scattering between phonon and phonon, phonon and impurity, or phonon and interface is regarded as the origin of thermal resistance, undesirous for thermal conduction. The indicators describing thermal conduction ability are thermal conductivity, λ, and thermal diffusivity, α, which are correlated by
=λ αρcp (1)
where ρ is density, cp is specific heat at a given pressure.

sections.heading: 2.2. Models and theory of thermal conduction of composites
sections.text:
Many models were tried to describe the thermal conduction of composites. One is Maxwell-Eucken model, written as

where λ, λm, λf are thermal conductivities of composites, matrices, and fillers, respectively, and V is volumetric fraction of fillers. This model is simple yet hardly practical, because it ignores the dispersion of fillers and the filler-matrix interaction.
The series-and-parallel model considers a composite to be separate fillers and matrices, which equation is

where ξ is a constant between 1 and -1. Specially, it stands for the series model when ξ is -1, while it represents the parallel one if ξ is 1. Based on Eq. (3), Agari et al. further deduced the equation as follows [29]
= + −λ VC λ V C λlg (1 ) lg( )m m f f (4)
where Cm relates with the crystallinity and crystal size of polymers, and Cf describes the ease in forming conductive chains or network of fillers. Although Cm and Cf are often experimentally or empirically determined, Agari model is practically effective for composite systems.
Based on the above models, the following factors influence the thermal conductivity of composites. i) The intrinsic thermal conductivity of fillers is the key, which is the origin of reinforcement effect.
ii) The matrix-filler and filler-filler interfaces can cause phonon scattering in composites, which lead to great thermal resistance. iii) The crystallinity of matrix is considered an important factor since impurity and defects can also result in phonon scattering. iv) The orientation of fillers is considered for achieving the anisotropic thermal conductivity. For instance, BN possesses a high thermal conductivity in (002) plane, experimentally up to 400W/mK, while the number declines to several in other orientations. It will assist anisotropic materials for special targets. v) The size, shape, and surface area of fillers also influence the heat flow.
3. Recent progress on thermal conductivity of BN-filled polymeric composites
Polymers dominate heat-dissipation packaging materials today, and epoxy occupies 98% of global market shares due to processing ease and low cost. Unfortunately, polymers including epoxy suffer from low thermal conductivity which limits their progressive applications. It is cost-effective to use a thermal conductive filler to enhance the thermal conductivity of polymers, although some complicated problems about fillers, matrices, and interfaces need to be addressed in such composites.
BN materials possess high thermal conductivity and electrical insulation, which makes them appropriate for electronic packaging [30]. Notably, BN stands out as one of the best fillers for insulating thermal conductive composites, considering its superior thermal conductivity comparing with other ceramic fillers. Comparing with micro-materials, BN nanomaterials are readily dispersed in polymer matrices and improve the fractions of intermediate phase, and they easily form thermal network within polymers. BN nanomaterials thus enjoy exceptional advantages as fillers of composites. BN nanomaterials with different dimensions behave differently as shown in Fig. 1. Herein we will expatiate on the BN/polymer composites with respect to the dimension of fillers.
3.1. 0D BN nanoparticle fillers
BN microparticles were early applied for the thermal enhancement of composites. As early as 1988, P. Bujard performed a composite of BN particles and epoxy, which thermal conductivity reached 2.3W/mK at 31 vol% BN [31]. The number of conducting ways could influence thermal conductivity, therefore the size and dispersion of fillers were regulated. Donnay et al. used a nanoparticle-microparticle mixture (with additional silane couping and ball-milling) to improve the dispersion of BN in epoxy as shown in Fig. 2a-c [32]. It showed an effective
improvement: thermal conductivity of 20 wt% BN/epoxy was 4 times higher than blank epoxy. Muratov et al. used chemical functionalization, the 3-amino-propyl-3-ethoxy-silane (APTES), to modify BN. The functionalized BN had better dispersion in polypropylene (PP) [33]. The thermal conductivity of such composites was doubled as compared with unfunctionalized BN/PP. Poly(cyclotriphosphazene-co-bisphenol A) (PCB) could be the functionalization agent as shown in Fig. 2d-f. The PCB-coated BN improved the thermal conductivity of BN/epoxy by 370% at 20 wt% BN loading [34].
BN platelets are a special kind of particle-like fillers, which has considerable orientation. Yuan et al. utilized magnetic fields to assemble BN platelets in a composite [35]. At 9.14 vol% BN, the composite with platelets oriented parallel to the heat flux direction outperformed others. Based on the orientation of BN, the filler-matrix interface was improved again. Shen et al. formed a polydopamine (PDA) shell on BN microplatelets, which increased the dispersion and interfacial interaction [36]. The composite filled by 10 vol% aligned BN@PDA showed a high thermal conductivity of 5.4W/mK.
Recently, the hot-pressing was widely used to get better orientation and connection between matrices and fillers. Ye et al. designed a BN platelets/thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) composite with well dispersion by hot-pressing induction [37]. It was striking that the composite remained mechanically flexible at 95 wt% BN loading. Such BN/ TPU exhibited a remarkable thermal conductivity of 50.3W/mK, 264 times as high as pristine TPU. Feng et al. designed vertically aligned BN flakes/polyolefin-elastomer composites by two-roll milling, hot compression and mechanical cutting [38]. The fabricated composite with 43.75 vol% BN showed the through-plane thermal conductivity of 6.94W/mK. Hu et al. fabricated BN platelets/epoxy via hot pressing, which led to ordered BN orientation and well enhancement [39]. Besides thermal conductivity, the hot pressing treatment often results in decent mechanical property, which is a promising technique towards high-performance polymeric composites.
3.2. 1D BNNT fillers
BNNT has a high thermal conductivity along the axial direction, yet
the large aspect ratio results in relatively poor dispersion in matrices. Since the concentration of fillers in composites plays an important role, such poor dispersibility of BNNT had rather limited the development of BNNT/polymer [40]. Until 2009, Zhi et al. put BNNT into a solution of polymers, followed by hot-pressing, to increase the filling fraction of BNNT up to 20–30wt% as shown in Fig. 3a-c [41]. The fabricated composites of polyvinyl-butyral (PVB), polymethyl-methacrylate (PMMA), polystyrene (PS), and polyethylene-vinyl alcohol (PEVA) possessed 8–20 fold increase in the thermal conductivity. Terao et al. modified BNNT with epicatechin gallate molecules, catechin. The modification can minimize the negative influence of interfaces, which put forward the thermal conductivity of polyvinyl-formal (PVF) by 160% at 1 wt% BNNT loading and that of polyvinyl-alcohol (PVA) by 270% at 3 wt% BNNT [42]. The covalent functionalization might degrade crystallinity of BN. Recently, Zeng et al. used cellulose nanofibers (CNF) to modify BNNT by noncovalent functionalization [43], which led to a strong interfacial interaction without degrading the crystalline structure of BNNT. The obtained CNF/BNNT composites showed a strikingly in-plane thermal conductivity of 21.39W/mK at 25 wt% BNNT.
A more interesting topic is the orientation of fillers. The heat-dissipation materials sometimes require the thermal conduction with anisotropic property. Considering that the (002) planes of BN have superior thermal conductivity, hence BNNT becomes a fascinating filler for anisotropic thermal conduction with high thermal conductivity along the axial direction. Terao et al. made a precise control of BNNT orientation in composites in 2010 as shown in Fig. 3d-f [44]. Regarding in-plane thermal conductivity, the oriented BNNT performed 5 times better than random BNNT fillers. The highly anisotropic heat-dissipation material is of great significance, which is in progress.
3.3. 2D BNNS fillers
Compared with 0D and 1D BN nanomaterials, BNNS can perform high thermal conductivity in two dimensions, and the dispersion of BNNS is easier than that of BNNT. In addition, single-layered BNNS have the highest thermal conductivity owing to the decrease of phonon-
phonon scattering. BNNS are thus popularly studied in composites. In 2012, Song et al. fabricated BNNS-filled epoxy [45]. The BN/epoxy exhibited a thermal conductivity of 30W/mK at 50 vol% BN. Cho et al. controlled the orientation of BNNS in a polymer matrix by magnetic field, which led to a remarkable increase of thermal diffusion by 300% [46]. Wu et al. fabricated the BNNS/poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA) film by vacuum filtration, which exhibited anisotropy and an in-plane thermal conductivity of 200W/mK at> 90wt% BN loading as shown in Fig. 4 [11]. The superior thermal conductivity was ascribed to the electrostatic combination of PDDA and BNNS.
Although BNNS are effective fillers, the high cost and the low output rather limit their progress. In 2013, Wang et al. utilized BNNS derived from a unique chemical blowing route for making BNNS/PMMA composites [22,47]. The BNNS/PMMA showed a significant 17-fold-enhanced thermal conductivity at 23 wt% BN (Fig. 5a-d). In 2014, Wang et al. further designed an cost-effective synthesis of BNNS via carbothermic reduction, and applied the BNNS to BN/epoxy as shown in Fig. 5e-g [24]. The composites reached a 14-fold increase in thermal conductivity at 40 wt% BN (Fig. 5h).
Improving filler-matrix interaction can facilitate the thermal conduction at low loading fraction. In 2015, Xiao et al. functionalized BNNS by steam to yield edge-modified OH-BNNS [48,50]. The OHBNNS/poly(N-isopropylalacrylamide) composites showed a 41%
improvement of thermal conductivity at 0.07 wt% fillers. The improvement was benefited from hydroxyl groups on the BNNS. Chen et al. fabricated PVA-BNNS fibers and rolled them into a vertically oriented PVA-BNNS cylinder, and then prepared a PVA-BNNS/polydimethylsiloxane composite [49]. The composite exhibited a 10 times enhancement of thermal conductivity at 15.6 vol% BN. Recently, Lei et al. synthesized a highly dispersible amino-functionalized BNNS [50], which was applied to a composite [51]. A ultra-high in-plane thermal conductivity of 28.2–120.7W/mK were achieved at 40–90wt% BN, because of the improvement of the concentration of BNNS and the interfacial compatibility.
3.4. 3D network-like BN fillers
The filler-filler and filler-matrix interfaces are the first troublesome matter in thermal conduction as aforementioned. In principle, a 3D BN network is the ultimate filler of thermal conductive composites because of no heterogeneous interfaces, resulting in the minimization of fillerfiller interfacial phonon scattering [52,54]. In 2015, Zeng et al. tried a 3D BNNS network by an ice-templated fabrication and incorporated it into epoxy by infiltration. The thermal conductivity of the BNNS/epoxy was 2.85W/mK at 9.29 vol% BNNS [53]. Recently, Jiang et al. designed a hydrogen-bond-regulated 3D BN network combined with polyamide-
imide (PAI), which exhibited a thermal conductivity of 1.17W/mK (409% enhancement) at 4 wt% BN [54]. Surface functionalization was additionally applied to modifying the interface of 3D BN. Huang et al. fabricated a 3D BNNS network based on CNF skeleton, and the CNFBNNS/epoxy composite demonstrated a thermal conductivity of 3.13W/mK at 9.6 vol% BN [55].
3.5. Multi-scale and multi-dimensional mixed BN fillers
To address BN-BN and BN-polymer interfacial problems, novel projects are proposed lately. Multi-scale design and multi-dimensional mixed BN fillers are important concepts. Donnay et al. mixed microparticles and nanoparticles of BN as fillers, which was an effective strategy to improve thermal conductivity as compared with a composite with mono-fillers at the same filling level [32]. Multi-dimensional fillers are also valid for establishing BN thermal chains. In 2013, Su et al. employed the hybrid BNNT-BNNS fillers (together with a noncovalent functionalization by 1-pyrenebutyric acid, PBA). The fabricated PBABNNT-BNNS/epoxy outperformed PBA-BNNT/epoxy and PBA-BNNS/ epoxy, owing to multi-dimensional effect of fillers [56].
To sum up, based on the superb thermal conductivity of BN, BN nanomaterials have been growing up as the advanced fillers of thermal conductive composites. The blooming studies about BN-reinforced
polymeric composites have sprung up, as selectively summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text:
BN is an ideal filler for thermal conductive composites for electronic packaging. It enjoys exceptionally high thermal conductivity (basically higher than other ceramic fillers) while keeps strong insulation (in contrast to carbon and metal fillers). It can further constrain the thermal expansion of polymers to match silicon substrates. BN also has low dielectric constants and loss to reduce the parasitic capacitance between interconnections of chips, and it has tremendous stability. These characteristics perfectly meet the requirements of electronic packaging.
This review discusses a whole picture from 0D to 3D BN nanomaterials as advanced fillers to enhance thermal conductivity of polymers. In history, 0D BN microparticles and nanoparticles are early developed as fillers, which induces follow-up studies. BNNT and BNNS are then applied to composites to achieve higher thermal conductivity. They are also used for manufacturing anisotropic composites via controlling orientation. Despite the prosperous progresses of BN-filled polymeric composites, it is a long way to reach high-performance industrial composites due to an army of difficulties. More efforts are firstly required for economically producing BN nanomaterials. More importantly, the dispersion of fillers and the interfaces between fillers and matrices are pivotal and inevitable issues. The functionalization can increase the miscibility to alleviate the interfacial resistance, yet there is a lot of room for improvement. The multi-scale and multi-dimensional mixed fillers are newly explored to ameliorate the interface issues. 3D fillers are emerging as a new concept to diminish the interfacial resistance as well as to decrease the filling fraction of fillers, but the manufacture of 3D BN fillers is in a nascent stage. With the progress addressing the issues, BN/polymer composites will expose splendid potentials and pave the way to numerous fantasy applications.

metadata.abstractText: The demand for insulating polymeric composites with high thermal conductivity has increased remarkably for electronic packaging. Since polymers usually suffer from low thermal conductivity, boron nitrides (BN) are emerging as advanced fillers in polymeric composites. BN nanomaterials strikingly reinforce thermal conductivity of polymers and simultaneously improve insulation, thermal expansion, and dielectricity. We herein introduce diverse BN nanomaterials and summarize the progress about thermal conductive composites with various BN fillers from 0D BN particles via 1D nanotubes to 2D nanosheets. 3D fillers, multi-scale and multidimensional mixed BN fillers developed recently are also presented. The functionalization and the controlled orientation of fillers are reviewed, and current challenges towards higher thermal conductivity of BN/polymer composites are additionally discussed.
